Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Communicate clearly and empathetically with patients and their families
Situation2: A patient is at a routine check-up and has general questions about their health.
Story: I glanced at my phone as I walked into the exam room, noticing a text from my younger sister: “Movie night with everyone at 7? Please come!” I smiled, remembering our promise to include each other in plans, to keep our bond strong. But as I greeted my patient, Mrs. Lee, I saw the worry in her eyes. She had a list of questions about her health, and I knew she needed my full attention and empathy. My mind tugged in two directions—my sister’s hope for togetherness, and my patient’s need for reassurance. I felt the weight of both expectations: to be the supportive sister who shows up, and the compassionate doctor who listens. My heart ached as I tried to focus on Mrs. Lee’s concerns, all the while feeling the pull of my sister’s invitation and the fear of letting her down.
